medical: NUCLEAR MEDICINE HEPATOBILIARY SCAN REASON FOR EXAM: Right upper quadrant pain. COMPARISONS: CT of the abdomen dated 02/13/09 and ultrasound of the abdomen dated 02/13/09. Radiopharmaceutical 6.9 mCi of Technetium-99m Choletec. FINDINGS: Imaging obtained up to 30 minutes after the injection of radiopharmaceutical shows a normal hepatobiliary transfer time. There is normal accumulation within the gallbladder. After the injection of 2.1 mcg of intravenous cholecystic _______, the gallbladder ejection fraction at 30 minutes was calculated to be 32% (normal is greater than 35%). The patient experienced 2/10 pain at 5 minutes after the injection of the radiopharmaceutical and the patient also complained of nausea. IMPRESSION: 1. Negative for acute cholecystitis or cystic duct obstruction. 2. Gallbladder ejection fraction just under the lower limits of normal at 32% that can be seen with very mild chronic cholecystitis.
layman:
**Nuclear Medicine Hepatobiliary Scan**

**Reason for exam:** Pain in the right upper part of the belly.

**Comparisons:** CT scan of the abdomen (02/13/09) and ultrasound of the abdomen (02/13/09).

**Procedure:** 6.9 mCi of Technetium‑99m Choletec was injected. Images were taken up to 30 minutes after injection.

**Findings:**  
- The liver and bile ducts worked normally and the gallbladder filled normally.  
- After giving 2.1 mcg of a drug that stimulates the gallbladder, the gallbladder ejection fraction (how well it empties) at 30 minutes was 32%. Normal is over 35%.  
- The patient felt pain rated 2 out of 10 five minutes after the injection and also felt nauseous.

**Impression:**  
1. No evidence of acute gallbladder inflammation or blockage of the cystic duct.  
2. The gallbladder ejection fraction is just below normal (32%) and can be seen with very mild chronic gallbladder inflammation.
